BiasDescription: Subjects will follow the protocol closer than others. The distortion in data due to different levels of protocol adherence can bias the outcome.
Example: Subjects are instructed to take an antibiotic regimen, but stop once they start feeling better. This data may not be usable or give biased measures of the treatment's efficacy.

BiasDescription: Subjects may respond differently due to being observed.
Example: Patients become anxious when visiting a health professional and getting their blood pressure measured. This can introduce bias when evaluating the efficacy of blood pressure medication.

BiasDescription: A systematic difference between subjects that are recruited early in the study vs. later.
Example: Assigning subjects to treatments based on when they arrive or sign up may introduce bias due to confounding factors that influence temporal order.

BiasDescription: A systemic bias for seeking, observing, and interpreting information in support of a prior belief.
Example: A scientist uncritically cites papers that support their hypothesis while detailing the flaws in papers that find evidence to the contrary.

BiasDescription: When one's beliefs and behavior conflict.
When one adopts behaviors, styles, beliefs because others are doing so.
Participants behave differently because they know they are being observed.
Example: Medical staff complied more with proper hand-washing practice more when they were being watched.

BiasDescription: Tendency for a novel effect or intervention to appear better when it is new.
Example: The first publication of a new phenomenon often exaggerates the effect size; several large-scale replications have found that actual effect sizes are 50-80% of what is initially reported.

BiasDescription: Observing or recording information with methods that can introduce subjectivity.
Example: Investigators who know whether subjects are part of the control or treatment arm may inadvertently round up or down in a systematic way.

BiasDescription: Differences resulting from either subject or investigator awareness of the assigned treatment group.
Example: Investigators know that one lineage of mice are hypothesized to be more docile, and treat the mice differently, resulting in measurable changes.

BiasDescription: Selectively reporting research or information based on the findings.
Example: A research team conducts 4 experiments to test a hypothesis, but end up only writing about 3 of them that were significant in the paper.

BiasDescription: Systematic under-representation of ethnic minority populations and inappropriate interpretation of disparities between racial groups.
Example: A systemic review of trails leading to FDA approvals showed race wasn't reported for a third of cases. Black and hispanic populations were underrepresented for those that did report.

BiasDescription: Subjects in study may differ from the population of interest based on the selection method.
Example: An investigator recruits university undergraduates to study the relationship between social media usage and mental health; but this sample may be unique in many ways relative to the general population that the findings appear to be relevant for.

BiasDescription: Participants volunteering to take part in a study have different characteristics from the general population of interest.
An error in interpreting statistical data that occurs when group attributes are used inappropriately when describing individuals.
Example: Smokers are at a higher risk for developing lung cancer; this does not mean that an individual smoker will develop lung cancer or is more at-risk than any non-smoker.

BiasDescription: Perceiving random noise or data as evidence of a real effect or pattern.
Example: When observing a random distribution of points, humans will ascribe meaning to clusters of points and empty spaces.

BiasDescription: A tendency for subjects to answer questions in a way that appears more favorable to others.
Example: Respondents inflate their answers when asked about their charitable contributions.

BiasDescription: Observers interpret the behaviors of others as related to personality rather than situational factors.
Example: I believe others are poor at planning when they show up late to a meeting, but attribute my own lateness to bad traffic.

BiasDescription: When making evaluations or judgments, relying on examples that come to mind more regularly.
Example: When asked what disease they are worried about, respondents may say a rare disease that is widely covered in the news rather than a common cold.

BiasDescription: Erroneous interpretations of a subset that has passed through a screening process, and overlooking the subset that did not pass.
Example: A lottery winner provides financial advice to buy lottery tickets because 'it worked for them'.

BiasDescription: Perceiving one's personal choices and judgments as more common than they actually are.
Example: A survey asks people to predict how much time others spend on social media - the results are close to the respondent's own behavior.
